MA 104: Ordinary Differential Equations - Lecture 8

Related: MA 104 Course Overview | Lecture 7 - MA104 | Lecture 9 & 10 - MA104

Review of Power Series

A power series centered at $x0$ is $$ \sum{m=0}^\infty am (x - x0)^m = a0 + a1(x-x0) + a2(x-x0)^2 + \cdots $$

  • $am$ are the coefficients.
  • $x0$ is the center.
The series converges at a point $x$ if the sequence of partial sums $$ SN(x) = \sum{m=0}^N am (x-x0)^m $$ converges (i.e., $\lim{N\to\infty} SN(x)$ exists).
  • Always converges at the center $x = x0$.
Absolute convergence at $x$: $$ \sum{m=0}^\infty |am| |x-x0|^m \quad \text{converges} $$ ‚Üí implies ordinary convergence.

Radius of Convergence $R$:
  • If the series converges at $x1 \neq x0$, it converges absolutely for $|x-x0| < |x1-x0|$.
  • If it diverges at $x1$, it diverges for $|x-x0| > |x1-x0|$.
  • There exists $R \geq 0$ (or $\infty$) such that the series converges for $|x-x0| < R$ and diverges for $|x-x0| > R$.
  • The interval $|x-x0| < R$ is the interval of convergence (endpoints must be checked separately).

Tests for Radius of Convergence

Root Test: $$ c = \limsup{n\to\infty} \sqrt[n]{|an|} \quad \Rightarrow \quad R = \frac{1}{c} $$
  • Converges if $c |x-x0| < 1$, diverges if $>1$.
Ratio Test (often easier): $$ L = \lim{n\to\infty} \left| \frac{a{n+1}}{an} \right| \quad \Rightarrow \quad R = \frac{1}{L} $$ (if limit exists). Examples:
  1. $\sum (-1)^n (x-2)^n$
$R=1$ ‚Üí converges for $1 < x < 3$.
  1. $\sum (-1)^n \frac{x^{2n}}{n^2 2^n}$
$R=\sqrt{2}$ (use ratio or root).

Differentiation & Integration of Power Series

If $\sum am (x-x0)^m = f(x)$ for $|x-x0| < R$ ($R>0$), then:

  • $f$ is continuous and infinitely differentiable on $|x-x0| < R$.
  • Term-by-term differentiation/integration is valid inside the radius:
$$ f'(x) = \sum{n=1}^\infty n an (x-x0)^{n-1} $$ $$ f''(x) = \sum{n=2}^\infty n(n-1) an (x-x0)^{n-2} $$ (both converge absolutely for $|x-x0| < R$).

Taylor Series of $f$ about $x0$: $$ f(x) = \sum{n=0}^\infty \frac{f^{(n)}(x0)}{n!} (x-x0)^n $$
  • $an = f^{(n)}(x0)/n!$.
Analytic function at $x0$: Can be represented by a power series (Taylor series) with positive radius of convergence around $x0$. Examples of analytic functions: $e^x$, $\sin x$, $\cos x$, polynomials, rational functions (except at poles). Vanishing coefficients: If $\sum am (x-x0)^m = 0$ for all $x$ in some interval around $x0$, then $am = 0$ for all $m$.

Index Shifting (Useful for ODEs)

It is often convenient to re-index sums so powers align.

Example: $$ \sum{n=2}^\infty an x^n = \sum{m=0}^\infty a{m+2} x^{m+2} $$ (Both contain exactly the same terms.)

Existence of Power Series Solutions

Theorem (Existence of Power Series Solutions): Consider $$ y'' + P(x)y' + Q(x)y = R(x) $$ If $P(x)$, $Q(x)$, $R(x)$ are analytic at $x=x0$, then every solution is analytic at $x0$ and can be represented by a power series in powers of $(x-x0)$ with positive radius of convergence.

Example: Power Series Solution of $y'' + y = 0$

Assume solution of form $$ y(x) = \sum{n=0}^\infty an x^n \quad (\text{centered at } 0) $$ Differentiate: $$ y' = \sum{n=1}^\infty n an x^{n-1}, \quad y'' = \sum{n=2}^\infty n(n-1) an x^{n-2} $$ Plug into ODE: $$ \sum{n=2}^\infty n(n-1) an x^{n-2} + \sum{n=0}^\infty an x^n = 0 $$ Shift index in first sum ($k=n-2$): $$ \sum{k=0}^\infty (k+2)(k+1) a{k+2} x^k + \sum{k=0}^\infty ak x^k = 0 $$ Combine: $$ \sum{k=0}^\infty \big[(k+2)(k+1) a{k+2} + ak\big] x^k = 0 $$ Recurrence: $$ (k+2)(k+1) a{k+2} + ak = 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad a{k+2} = -\frac{ak}{(k+2)(k+1)} $$ Even and odd coefficients separate:

  • Even: $a{2k} = \frac{(-1)^k}{(2k)!} a0$
  • Odd: $a{2k+1} = \frac{(-1)^k}{(2k+1)!} a1$
Thus $$ y(x) = a0 \sum{k=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^k}{(2k)!} x^{2k} + a1 \sum{k=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^k}{(2k+1)!} x^{2k+1} = a0 \cos x + a1 \sin x $$ (Ratio test confirms $R=\infty$).

Summary of Lecture 8

  • Power series: Definition, convergence, radius $R$, interval of convergence.
  • Tests: Root test, ratio test for $R$.
  • Operations: Term-by-term differentiation/integration valid inside radius.
  • Taylor series: Representation of analytic functions.
  • Power series solutions: Exist (and are unique) when $P,Q,R$ analytic ‚Üí solve via recurrence relation on coefficients.
  • Classic example: $y'' + y = 0$ recovers $\cos x$ and $\sin x$ series.
Key Takeaway: Analytic coefficients guarantee analytic solutions expandable as power series ‚Äî the foundation for series solutions of ODEs with variable coefficients. Next: More applications of series solutions, Frobenius method for singular points.
